How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

The real problem isn't the time that kids spend on their smart phones, tablets or computer screens.
 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there is a real risk. Just because society has shifted its focus to a more pressing issue, doesn't mean that we don't still have a screen time problem. 
The real problem isn't the time that kids spend on their smart phones, tablets or computer screens.
 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time.  The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use

 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for ki

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there is a real risk. Just because society has shifted its focus to a more pressing issue, doesn't mean that we don't still have a screen time problem. 
The real problem isn't the time that kids spend on their smart phones, tablets or computer screens.
 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there is a real risk. Just because society has shifted its focus to a more pressing issue, doesn't mean that we don't still have a screen time problem. 
The real problem isn't the time that kids spend on their smart phones, tablets or computer screens.
 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks.

The real problem isn't the time that kids spend on their smart phones, tablets or computer screens.
 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good the

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there is a real risk. Just because society has shifted its focus to a more pressing issue, doesn't mean that we don't still have a screen time problem. 
The real problem isn't the time that kids spend on their smart phones, tablets or computer screens.
 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there, but as with anything else

 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there, but as with anything else, there can be such a thing as

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there is a real risk. Just because society has shifted its focus to a more pressing issue, doesn't mean that we don't still have a screen time problem. 
The real problem isn't the time that kids spend on their smart phones, tablets or computer screens.
 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.

 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.
 Too many kids have been living through the p

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there is a real risk. Just because society has shifted its focus to a more pressing issue, doesn't mean that we don't still have a screen time problem. 
The real problem isn't the time that kids spend on their smart phones, tablets or computer screens.
 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.
 Too many kids have been living through the pandemic in isolation. Th

We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there is a real risk. Just because society has shifted its focus to a more pressing issue, doesn't mean that we don't still have a screen time problem. 
The real problem isn't the time that kids spend on their smart phones, tablets or computer screens.
 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen.

There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing.

 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.
 Too many kids have been living through the pandemic in isolation. They haven't had the opportunity to go out and build new, real world, relat

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there is a real risk. Just because society has shifted its focus to a more pressing issue, doesn't mean that we don't still have a screen time problem. 
The real problem isn't the time that kids spend on their smart phones, tablets or computer screens.
 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. The real problem isn't the time that kids spend on their smart phones, tablets or computer screens.
 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.
 Too many kids have been living through the pandemic in isolation. They haven't had the opportunity to go out and build new, real world, relationships. That has led t

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.
 Too many kids have been living through the pandemic in isolation. They haven't had the opportunity to go out and build new, real world, relationships. That has led to a lot more screen time

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there is a real risk. Just because society has shifted its focus to a more pressing issue, doesn't mean that we don't still have a screen time problem. 
The real problem isn't the time that kids spend on their smart phones, tablets or computer screens.
 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use

There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing.

It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.
 Too many kids have been living through the pandemic in isolation. They haven't had the opportunity to go out and build new, real world, relationships. That has led to a lot more screen time than ever before. The more that kids use their screen devices, the less time they have for human contact and interaction in the real world. Si

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there is a real risk. Just because society has shifted its focus to a more pressing issue, doesn't mean that we don't still have a screen time problem. 
The real problem isn't the time that kids spend on their smart phones, tablets or computer screens.
 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.

That has led to a lot more screen time than ever before. The more that kids use their screen devices, the less time they have for human contact and interaction in the real world. Sin

These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.
 Too many kids have been living through the pandemic in isolation. They haven't had the opportunity to go out and build new, real world, relationships. That has led to a lot more screen time than ever before. The more that kids use their screen devices, the less time they have for human contact and interaction in the real world. Since many of them have b

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there is a real risk. Just because society has shifted its focus to a more pressing issue, doesn't mean that we don't still have a screen time problem. 
The real problem isn't the time that kids spend on their smart phones, tablets or computer screens.
 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. The real problem isn't the time that kids spend on their smart phones, tablets or computer screens.
 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.
 Too many kids have been living through the pandemic in isolation. They haven't had the opportunity to go out and build new, real world, relationships. That has led to a lot more screen time than ever before. The more that kids use their screen devices, the less time they have for human contact and interaction in the real world. Since many of them have been stuck at home, the

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

 Too many kids have been living through the pandemic in isolation. They haven't had the opportunity to go out and build new, real world, relationships. That has led to a lot more screen time than ever before. The more that kids use their screen devices, the less time they have for human contact and interaction in the real world. Since many of them have been stuck at home, if they don't g

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there is a real risk. Just because society has shifted its focus to a more pressing issue, doesn't mean that we don't still have a screen time problem. 
The real problem isn't the time that kids spend on their smart phones, tablets or computer screens.
 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.
 Too many kids have been living through the pandemic in isolation. They haven't had the opportunity to go out and build new, real world, relationships. That has led to a lot more screen time than ever before. The more that kids use their screen devices, the less time they have for human contact and interaction in the real world. Since many of them have been stuck at home, if they don't ge

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there is a real risk. Just because society has shifted its focus to a more pressing issue, doesn't mean that we don't still have a screen time problem. 
The real problem isn't the time that kids spend on their smart phones, tablets or computer screens.
 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.
 Too many kids have been living through the pandemic in isolation. They haven't had the opportunity to go out and build new, real world, relationships. That has led to a lot more screen time than ever before. The more that kids use their screen devices, the less time they have for human contact and interaction in the real world. Since many of them have been stuck at home, if they don't get that interaction f

 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.
 Too many kids have been living through the pandemic in isolation. They haven't had the opportunity to go out and build new, real world, relationships. That has led to a lot more screen time than ever before. The more that kids use their screen devices, the less time they have for human contact and interaction in the real world. Since many of them have been stuck at home, if they don't get that interaction from immediate famil

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.
 Too many kids have been living through the pandemic in isolation. They haven't had the opportunity to go out and build new, real world, relationships. That has led to a lot more screen time than ever before. The more that kids use their screen devices, the less time they have for human contact and interaction in the real world. Since many of them have been stuck at home, if they don't get that interaction from immediate family they find that they

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

In my opinion, there is a real risk. Just because society has shifted its focus to a more pressing issue, doesn't mean that we don't still have a screen time problem. 
The real problem isn't the time that kids spend on their smart phones, tablets or computer screens.
 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.
 Too many kids have been living through the pandemic in isolation. They haven't had the opportunity to go out and build new, real world, relationships. That has led to a lot more screen time than ever before. The more that kids use their screen devices, the less time they have for human contact and interaction in the real world. Since many of them have been stuck at home, if they don't get that interaction from immediate family they find that they can get it online. 

Unfortunately, the need for physical interaction pressures anyone that doesn't have a lot of friends to begin craving more and more screen time.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there is a real risk. Just because society has shifted its focus to a more pressing issue, doesn't mean that we don't still have a screen time problem. 
The real problem isn't the time that kids spend on their smart phones, tablets or computer screens.
 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.
 Too many kids have been living through the pandemic in isolation. They haven't had the opportunity to go out and build new, real world, relationships. That has led to a lot more screen time than ever before. The more that kids use their screen devices, the less time they have for human contact and interaction in the real world. Since many of them have been stuck at home, if they don't get that interaction from immediate family they find that they can get it online. 

Unfortunately, the need for physical interaction pressures anyone that doesn't have a lot of friends to begin craving more and more screen time. It's an addiction,

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there is a real risk. Just because society has shifted its focus to a more pressing issue, doesn't mean that we don't still have a screen time problem. 
The real problem isn't the time that kids spend on their smart phones, tablets or computer screens.
 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.
 Too many kids have been living through the pandemic in isolation. They haven't had the opportunity to go out and build new, real world, relationships. That has led to a lot more screen time than ever before. The more that kids use their screen devices, the less time they have for human contact and interaction in the real world. Since many of them have been stuck at home, if they don't get that interaction from immediate family they find that they can get it online. 

Unfortunately, the need for physical interaction pressures anyone that doesn't have a lot of friends to begin craving more and more screen time. It's an addiction, and it should be tre

We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.
 Too many kids have been living through the pandemic in isolation. They haven't had the opportunity to go out and build new, real world, relationships. That has led to a lot more screen time than ever before. The more that kids use their screen devices, the less time they have for human contact and interaction in the real world. Since many of them have been stuck at home, if they don't get that interaction from immediate family they find that they can get it online. 

Unfortunately, the need for physical interaction pressures anyone that doesn't have a lot of friends to begin craving more and more screen time. It's an addiction, and it should be treated as such. We do

That has led to a lot more screen time than ever before. The more that kids use their screen devices, the less time they have for human contact and interaction in the real world. Since many of them have been stuck at home, if they don't get that interaction from immediate family they find that they can get it online. 

Unfortunately, the need for physical interaction pressures anyone that doesn't have a lot of friends to begin craving more and more screen time. It's an addiction, and it should be treated as such. We don't encourage add

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there is a real risk. Just because society has shifted its focus to a more pressing issue, doesn't mean that we don't still have a screen time problem. 
The real problem isn't the time that kids spend on their smart phones, tablets or computer screens.
 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.
 Too many kids have been living through the pandemic in isolation. They haven't had the opportunity to go out and build new, real world, relationships. That has led to a lot more screen time than ever before. The more that kids use their screen devices, the less time they have for human contact and interaction in the real world. Since many of them have been stuck at home, if they don't get that interaction from immediate family they find that they can get it online. 

Unfortunately, the need for physical interaction pressures anyone that doesn't have a lot of friends to begin craving more and more screen time. It's an addiction, and it should be treated as such. We don't encourage addi

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there is a real risk. Just because society has shifted its focus to a more pressing issue, doesn't mean that we don't still have a screen time problem. 
The real problem isn't the time that kids spend on their smart phones, tablets or computer screens.
 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.
 Too many kids have been living through the pandemic in isolation. They haven't had the opportunity to go out and build new, real world, relationships. That has led to a lot more screen time than ever before. The more that kids use their screen devices, the less time they have for human contact and interaction in the real world. Since many of them have been stuck at home, if they don't get that interaction from immediate family they find that they can get it online. 

Unfortunately, the need for physical interaction pressures anyone that doesn't have a lot of friends to begin craving more and more screen time. It's an addiction, and it should be treated as such. We don't encourage addicts to continue to

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there is a real risk. Just because society has shifted its focus to a more pressing issue, doesn't mean that we don't still have a screen time problem. 
The real problem isn't the time that kids spend on their smart phones, tablets or computer screens.
 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.
 Too many kids have been living through the pandemic in isolation. They haven't had the opportunity to go out and build new, real world, relationships. That has led to a lot more screen time than ever before. The more that kids use their screen devices, the less time they have for human contact and interaction in the real world. Since many of them have been stuck at home, if they don't get that interaction from immediate family they find that they can get it online.

 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.
 Too many kids have been living through the pandemic in isolation. They haven't had the opportunity to go out and build new, real world, relationships. That has led to a lot more screen time than ever before. The more that kids use their screen devices, the less time they have for human contact and interaction in the real world. Since many of them have been stuck at home, if they don't get that interaction from immediate family they find that they can get it online. 

Unfortunately, the need for physical interaction pressures anyone that doesn't have a lot of friends to begin craving more and more screen time. It's an addiction, and it should be treated as such. We don't encourage addicts to continue to use. We shouldn't

We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.
 Too many kids have been living through the pandemic in isolation. They haven't had the opportunity to go out and build new, real world, relationships. That has led to a lot more screen time than ever before. The more that kids use their screen devices, the less time they have for human contact and interaction in the real world. Since many of them have been stuck at home, if they don't get that interaction from immediate family they find that they can get it online. 

Unfortunately, the need for physical interaction pressures anyone that doesn't have a lot of friends to begin craving more and more screen time. It's an addiction, and it should be treated as such. We don't encourage addicts to continue to use. We shouldn't encourage kids us

We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.
 Too many kids have been living through the pandemic in isolation. They haven't had the opportunity to go out and build new, real world, relationships. That has led to a lot more screen time than ever before. The more that kids use their screen devices, the less time they have for human contact and interaction in the real world. Since many of them have been stuck at home, if they don't get that interaction from immediate family they find that they can get it online. 

Unfortunately, the need for physical interaction pressures anyone that doesn't have a lot of friends to begin craving more and more screen time. It's an addiction, and it should be treated as such. We don't encourage addicts to continue to use. We shouldn't encourage kids using their devices

The real problem isn't the time that kids spend on their smart phones, tablets or computer screens.
 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.
 Too many kids have been living through the pandemic in isolation. They haven't had the opportunity to go out and build new, real world, relationships. That has led to a lot more screen time than ever before. The more that kids use their screen devices, the less time they have for human contact and interaction in the real world. Since many of them have been stuck at home, if they don't get that interaction from immediate family they find that they can get it online. 

Unfortunately, the need for physical interaction pressures anyone that doesn't have a lot of friends to begin craving more and more screen time. It's an addiction, and it should be treated as such. We don't encourage addicts to continue to use. We shouldn't encourage kids using their devices for 18 hours of a 24

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there is a real risk. Just because society has shifted its focus to a more pressing issue, doesn't mean that we don't still have a screen time problem. 
The real problem isn't the time that kids spend on their smart phones, tablets or computer screens.
 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.
 Too many kids have been living through the pandemic in isolation. They haven't had the opportunity to go out and build new, real world, relationships. That has led to a lot more screen time than ever before. The more that kids use their screen devices, the less time they have for human contact and interaction in the real world. Since many of them have been stuck at home, if they don't get that interaction from immediate family they find that they can get it online. 

Unfortunately, the need for physical interaction pressures anyone that doesn't have a lot of friends to begin craving more and more screen time. It's an addiction, and it should be treated as such. We don't encourage addicts to continue to use. We shouldn't encourage kids using their devices for 18 hours of a 24 hour day to contin

There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.
 Too many kids have been living through the pandemic in isolation. They haven't had the opportunity to go out and build new, real world, relationships. That has led to a lot more screen time than ever before. The more that kids use their screen devices, the less time they have for human contact and interaction in the real world. Since many of them have been stuck at home, if they don't get that interaction from immediate family they find that they can get it online. 

Unfortunately, the need for physical interaction pressures anyone that doesn't have a lot of friends to begin craving more and more screen time. It's an addiction, and it should be treated as such. We don't encourage addicts to continue to use. We shouldn't encourage kids using their devices for 18 hours of a 24 hour day to continue staring at th

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

In my opinion, there is a real risk. Just because society has shifted its focus to a more pressing issue, doesn't mean that we don't still have a screen time problem. 
The real problem isn't the time that kids spend on their smart phones, tablets or computer screens.
 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use

---

In my opinion, there is a real risk. Just because society has shifted its focus to a more pressing issue, doesn't mean that we don't still have a screen time problem. 
The real problem isn't the time that kids spend on their smart phones, tablets or computer screens.
 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. Unfortunately, the need for physical interaction pressures anyone that doesn't have a lot of friends to begin craving more and more screen time. It's an addiction, and it should be treated as such. We don't encourage addicts to continue to use. We shouldn't encourage kids using their devices for 18 hours of a 24 hour day to continue staring at the screen. Humans have a natural need for human contact and all of us, kids and adults, need the real world interaction even-more during stressful times like this

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there is a real risk. Just because society has shifted its focus to a more pressing issue, doesn't mean that we don't still have a screen time problem. 
The real problem isn't the time that kids spend on their smart phones, tablets or computer screens.
 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.
 Too many kids have been living through the pandemic in isolation. They haven't had the opportunity to go out and build new, real world, relationships. That has led to a lot more screen time than ever before. The more that kids use their screen devices, the less time they have for human contact and interaction in the real world. Since many of them have been stuck at home, if they don't get that interaction from immediate family they find that they can get it online. 

Unfortunately, the need for physical interaction pressures anyone that doesn't have a lot of friends to begin craving more and more screen time. It's an addiction, and it should be treated as such. We don't encourage addicts to continue to use. We shouldn't encourage kids using their devices for 18 hours of a 24 hour day to continue staring at the screen. Humans have a natural need for human contact and all of us, kids and adults, need the real world interaction even-more during stressful times like this

We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.
 Too many kids have been living through the pandemic in isolation. They haven't had the opportunity to go out and build new, real world, relationships. That has led to a lot more screen time than ever before. The more that kids use their screen devices, the less time they have for human contact and interaction in the real world. Since many of them have been stuck at home, if they don't get that interaction from immediate family they find that they can get it online. 

Unfortunately, the need for physical interaction pressures anyone that doesn't have a lot of friends to begin craving more and more screen time. It's an addiction, and it should be treated as such. We don't encourage addicts to continue to use. We shouldn't encourage kids using their devices for 18 hours of a 24 hour day to continue staring at the screen. Humans have a natural need for human contact and all of us, kids and adults, need the real world interaction even-more during stressful times like this

We don't encourage addicts to continue to use. We shouldn't encourage kids using their devices for 18 hours of a 24 hour day to continue staring at the screen. Humans have a natural need for human contact and all of us, kids and adults, need the real world interaction even-more during stressful times like this

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there is a real risk. Just because society has shifted its focus to a more pressing issue, doesn't mean that we don't still have a screen time problem. 
The real problem isn't the time that kids spend on their smart phones, tablets or computer screens.
 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.
 Too many kids have been living through the pandemic in isolation. They haven't had the opportunity to go out and build new, real world, relationships. That has led to a lot more screen time than ever before. The more that kids use their screen devices, the less time they have for human contact and interaction in the real world. Since many of them have been stuck at home, if they don't get that interaction from immediate family they find that they can get it online. 

Unfortunately, the need for physical interaction pressures anyone that doesn't have a lot of friends to begin craving more and more screen time. It's an addiction, and it should be treated as such. We don't encourage addicts to continue to use. We shouldn't encourage kids using their devices for 18 hours of a 24 hour day to continue staring at the screen. Humans have a natural need for human contact and all of us, kids and adults, need the real world interaction even-more during stressful times like this

 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen. 
We saw with this pandemic and the way society responded that most parents did not have a sufficient amount of control over how their children could use
 their devices. It is common today for kids to have access to their own screen, and many of them have built a simulated life on the networks. These networks have digital stores, simulated cities that are part of multiplayer games, and have access to an online news station that keeps kids up with current events. There is a lot of good there but, as with anything else, there can be such a thing as too much of a good thing. 
It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.
 Too many kids have been living through the pandemic in isolation. They haven't had the opportunity to go out and build new, real world, relationships. That has led to a lot more screen time than ever before. The more that kids use their screen devices, the less time they have for human contact and interaction in the real world. Since many of them have been stuck at home, if they don't get that interaction from immediate family they find that they can get it online. 

Unfortunately, the need for physical interaction pressures anyone that doesn't have a lot of friends to begin craving more and more screen time. It's an addiction, and it should be treated as such. We don't encourage addicts to continue to use. We shouldn't encourage kids using their devices for 18 hours of a 24 hour day to continue staring at the screen. Humans have a natural need for human contact and all of us, kids and adults, need the real world interaction even-more during stressful times like this

It's time to begin talking about the opposite of screen time, which is life time.
 Too many kids have been living through the pandemic in isolation. They haven't had the opportunity to go out and build new, real world, relationships. That has led to a lot more screen time than ever before. The more that kids use their screen devices, the less time they have for human contact and interaction in the real world. Since many of them have been stuck at home, if they don't get that interaction from immediate family they find that they can get it online. 

Unfortunately, the need for physical interaction pressures anyone that doesn't have a lot of friends to begin craving more and more screen time. It's an addiction, and it should be treated as such. We don't encourage addicts to continue to use. We shouldn't encourage kids using their devices for 18 hours of a 24 hour day to continue staring at the screen. Humans have a natural need for human contact and all of us, kids and adults, need the real world interaction even-more during stressful times like this

I believe that the best thing we can do for our kids is to give them the in

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there is a real risk. Just because society has shifted its focus to a more pressing issue, doesn't mean that we don't still have a screen time problem. 
The real problem isn't the time that kids spend on their smart phones, tablets or computer screens.
 The problem is what they do with that time. We've watched them, through the pandemic, learn from virtual classrooms. This is an example of good screen time. We have also seen many children submerge into online gaming to an unhealthy level, as well as some other social networking applications that have created a diversion that leads to an unhealthy amount of time on a screen.
